Issues.Title: Remove 'Zero Width No-Brake Space' character from multiple files
Issues.Body:
## Description
Many files have non-breaking, zero-length spaces `UTF8-EFBBBF` that are not part of the standard character palette used in software development.  
PR introduces only cosmetic changes in the code, to not confuse while editing the code.

## Customer Impact
The end user does not feel the change, the developer may notice less strange behavior from the editor.

## Testing
The project builds up and runs fine after removing unnecessary characters.

## Risk
With a high probability - none, we just remove unnecessary, non-standard characters.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/6570)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove 'Zero Width No-Brake Space' character from multiple files" (#6570)

Issues.Title: [Port .NET 5.0 ] Fixes rounding error while glyphrun serialization
Issues.Body:
Fixes # <!-- Issue Number --> #6525 

Main PR <!-- Link to PR if any that fixed this in the main branch. --> #6295

## Description
When we serialize a GlyphRun to an XPS file, the advance widths for each glyph are rounded to an integer separately, thus producing a significant difference between the rendered output in the file and on the screen. This PR fixes the rounding, by taking into account the cumulative rounding error from the previous glyphs while rounding the current glyph.

## Customer Impact
Affects the visual fidelity of WPF Applications.
<!-- What is the impact to customers of not taking this fix? -->

## Regression

No

## Testing

Ad-Hoc testing. Tried with different sample apps.

## Risk
Less
<!-- Please assess the risk of taking this fix. Provide details backing up your assessment. -->

Issues.Title: Remove FriendAccessAllowedAttribute usage
Issues.Body:
## Description
Remove FriendAccessAllowedAttribute usage since it is not enforced in .Net Core. FriendAccessAllowedAttribute is an undocumented and non-public attribute which is not supported anymore. To use `FriendAccessAllowedAttribute`, when supported, you need to set [InternalsVisibleToAttribute.AllInternalsVisible](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.runtime.compilerservices.internalsvisibletoattribute.allinternalsvisible) to false, which is never set in this repo.

There are modifications to generated files in `src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationCore/System/Windows/Generated` but these files are generated from [Elements.cs](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/6561/files#diff-cafc35f65c4ad3fe1ce32cde276636fb77ba8c17fd1344a3371679dc1ad9137f) which is not runnable in this repo right now (dotnet/wpf#6135) but it should be fine because once we can run MilCodeGen, there shouldn't be any diffs.

## Customer Impact
None.

## Regression
No.

## Testing
Local build + CI.

## Risk
Low.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/6561)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove FriendAccessAllowedAttribute usage" (#6561)

Issues.Title: Image Source fails to load an image if application path has hash sign in it
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 6.0.4
* Windows version: Windows 11 21H2
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/main/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**
It is possible to specify Image source with relative path in XAML definition:
`Icon="Images/app.dark.png"`
However, this definition fails to load image if the path containing application has `#` symbol.
 
 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
In .Net 6
Fails in `BitmapDecoder.SetupDecoderFromUriOrStream` with `System.IO.DirectoryNotFoundException`
which transforms to exception going out:
`System.Windows.Markup.XamlParseException: "System.Windows.Baml2006.TypeConverterMarkupExtension" throws an exception."`

 **Expected behavior:**
 We should load image with relative path without crash.

 **Minimal repro:**
1. Create a WPF application
2. Add image in subfolder and specify its Build Action as Content and Copy to Output Directory as Copy or Copy if newer
3. Specify main window Icon image with relative path
`<Window x:Class="WpfApp1.MainWindow"
        Icon="Images/app.dark.png">`
4. Start an application and check everything is okay
5. Rename the project path into `#WpfApp1`
6. Start an application
7. Get an exception shown above
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Image Source fails to load an image if application path has hash sign in it" (#6560)

Issues.Title: optimistic TrackValue check, supporting not anymore connected columns
Issues.Body:
## User Story
I had an issue where I manipulated the `Columns` property of a DataGrid by removing a column. This resulted in a null-reference issue because the `TrackValue` method of the internal class `CellAutomationValueHolder` references to `column.DataGridOwner` which was not set anymore for the DataGridColumn since it was removed.

This is not a default (and maybe not wanted) behavior, but I think WPF should use here an optimistic check.

## Description
Adding a optimistic check by ignoring all `TrackValue` calls where the `DataGridOwner` property of the column is not set.


## Customer Impact

Might throw a null-reference-exception from `System.Windows.Automation.Peers.UIElementAutomationPeer.FromElement(UIElement element)` which is called within the `CellAutomationValueHolder.TrackValue` method.


## Testing

CI

## Risk

None

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/6553)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "optimistic TrackValue check, supporting not anymore connected columns" (#6553)

Issues.Title: Rely on Visual- not LogicalParent in GridSplitter
Issues.Body:
`GridSplitter` should rely on its `VisualParent` not it's `LogicalParent`

Fixes #6490

## Description
`GridSplitter` needs to interact with it's parent, this however should be the Visual and not the Logical parent.

## Customer Impact

GridSplitters do not work in `IsItemsHost` scenarios.


## Testing

I copied the modified code since I havent managed to build WPF yet.

## Risk

I dont think it is possible to use a `ControlTemplate` for a `Grid`, so `VisualParent` should generally be the more suitable solution

Issues.Title: Ignore NotImplementedException from ITaskbarList
Issues.Body:
Fixes #2377

## Description

In some cases, not closer specified in the documentation, [ITaskbarList::HrInit](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/shobjidl_core/nf-shobjidl_core-itaskbarlist-hrinit) can fail. When that happens, WPF applications setting `Window.TaskbarItemInfo` crash without possibility of gracefully handling the error.

This PR fixes the issue by checking for the result of HrInit, and not proceeding with taskbar customization if it fails, as per the documentation. "Not proceeding" simply means returning from the `ApplyTaskbarItemInfo` method the same way it is done in the method in other cases (e.g. API not supported by OS).

## Customer Impact

Application crashes when it sets `TaskbarItemInfo` and the API fails. Reports in #2377 indicate this happens in cases when no user is logged in, a custom shell without taskbar is used, or under terminal services.

## Regression

No.

## Testing

Built and verified that `TaskbarItemInfo` is still working on 7.0-preview3. Closed Explorer and verified the app crashes before the fix and does not crash after the fix, and that the taskbar info still gets applied when Explorer is restarted. Verified the error is appears in the trace output.

## Risk

I believe the risk is minimal. There is no changes to public API. There is a behavior change in an internal interface (no longer throws exceptions on error), but the fixed method is the only callsite currently using it. The handle to `ITaskbarList` is released in the `finally` block as per the documentation.

A valid worry is that throwing an exception is actually the desired outcome when taskbar is not available and application tries to use it. However, since the code already simply ignores other cases when this API is not available and developers cannot easily catch or avoid the exception, ignoring the error seems to be a consistent and justifiable behavior.




###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/6547)
